data.text: Do You Recommend Flat Protector Tube Liner?
Does anyone have experience with this product? Do you recommend it?
No, i recommend good tires with antipuncture system like schwalbe maraton pro
data.author: Zuk Zukowski

data.text: Just as said, No. Just get really good tyres..
data.author: Dylan Thomas

data.text: waste of money and effort ü§£ worst thing is those liner can fold and puncture your inner tube. like everyone‚Äôs said, go with good tires and if possible go tubeless, sealant helps a lot
data.author: M.P Anindito

data.text: I had a feeling it was too good to be true
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: You're right. I've had exactly that problem with these things.
data.author: Michael Hudson

data.text: I tried something similar. Bloody awful faf and pretty useless
data.author: Alex Gee

data.text: blew my front tandem tube and tyre.
data.author: Hugh Wilson

data.text: Pretty sure it caused punctured too. Had a lot at the time. Which is rather missing the point
data.author: Alex Gee

data.text: I bought some Schwale marathons 2 years ago, but have yet to fit themI like my panaracer paserelas I always had. Nice ride and grippyif not not very puncture proof the schwalbes look a bit plastic and skiddy?
data.author: Alex Gee

data.text: they're heavy and on the tandem I've had three or four sidewalls blow out. Sent two new back to supplier with bulges in the sidewall. Moved to Maxxis.
data.author: Hugh Wilson

data.text: Were the schwalbes grippy enough?
data.author: Alex Gee

data.text: yes... just dodgy build.
data.author: Hugh Wilson

data.text: I use the Conti Gatorskins on my road bike,no need for any liners. And as far as mountain bike tires,if You buy quality tires and tubes,really shouldn't need the liners.
data.author: James Patterson

data.text: Thanks for the advice. The truth is I just had my bike stolen last month after putting Schwalbe Marathons on it and I've got another bike that I love but kinda balked at putting down the money for another set of Schwalbes right away. I probably will get some soon since i'm in the US southwest and goathead season is soon.
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: I used something like those back in the late ‚Äò80s when I moved to Albuquerque and learned about goatheads the hard way. They were effective, but heavy. Tires and sealants have come a long way since then.
data.author: Rick Leach

data.text: I have only had a Schwalbe Marathon Plus tire pierced twice: by a nail from discarded lumber, and by ****ing goathead. In fairness that was over the course of thousands of miles in goathead territory. It may be worth looking at tubeless for the increased comfort and lower weight compared to the Marathon+. The two times I had to change those Marathon+ roadside it was a real challenge. Again, that was in the course of thousands of miles of cycling.
data.author: Abe Granderson

data.text: I usually get 8 to 10,000 miles out of marathon pluses before needing to change them. I‚Äôve only had one flat ever with those tires and it was a giant fish hookÔøº
data.author: Jeremie Smith

data.text: yep even with the Marathons I would get a goathead flat about once a month. But that beats every single day
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: , yea, marathon pluses are amazing. I went 10,000 miles on my front tire with zero flats. Typically for my rear tire, I get around 5000-6000 miles because that it where I have all my weight when touring. Their main cryptonite that I‚Äôve experienced is with thin metal wires on the road
data.author: Steve S Gordon

data.text: If you get the slime tubes be careful not to pinch them under the tyre - ¬£8 down the shitter üòÇ
data.author: Paul Breslin
Paul Breslin

data.text: Yes and no: before i was able to buy a couple of good tires, I used a pair of those for many years. I had them on my everyday mtb, with very cheap tires. And for 4 or 5 years never had a puncture. I would buy them if I couldnt afford good tires. Im sorry, But I feel nobody on this site realizes that a lot of people cant afford things like expensive tires But still want to travel. Open your minds and consider the money issue instead of repeating "buy good tires". I read opinions like these and it makes me wanna smack them.
data.author: Juan Manuel Abago

data.text: cut some old pet bottles and tape them tpghether - same benefits but for free
data.author: Fast Fuso

data.text: way back kids used to cut old tires and use them the same way
data.author: Juan Manuel Abago

data.text: Learn how to repair flats correctly and you will fear them less. Then you can use tires that offer a better ride and handle better than something like the Marathon. It only takes about 10 mins to replace the tube in the rear tire of a fully loaded touring bike if you know how. Less with experience. Practice at home. All that said, riding very good tires, that do not have all that puncture protection, that ride and handle wonderfully, I have not had a flat in over 4 years touring all over the world. Final note. Many talk about the weight of components and equipment and then add 2 or 3 pounds to each wheel with puncture protection!
data.author: Bill Heimann

data.text: , no flat in 4 years, and you don‚Äôt use a sealant of any kind? How many miles have you gone in 4 years, and on how many tires?
data.author: Steve S Gordon

data.text: I tried something similar (Mr. Tuffy liners) and completed both the US East and West Coasts without a single flat. Bit of a weight penalty, but not too big of a deal on a fully loaded touring bike. üö¥‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
data.author: Todd Burgman

data.text: Worked very good for me, when my puncture resistent tires (Schwalbe mondial) were half worne. Put another 20.000 kms on them. But all puncture resistent tires are super slow, tubeless is the thing for me now - 2 years without any flat...
data.author: Fast Fuso

data.text: When I used to have a touring bike I took the valve out of the innertube, put some sealant in, valve back in and pumped up.
data.author: Andrew Harris

data.text: , that‚Äôs what I do now too and it seems to work great! I had tried different tire liners and most were a waste of money.
data.author: Steve S Gordon

data.text: DO NOT USE THEM. I had these on my first tour and I got a flat every single gle day because they had hardened and cracked, which sliced my tubes open every 40ish miles
data.author: Spencer Steelman

data.text: me too
data.author: Bruce Dixon

data.text: yikes. Good to know, thanks!
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: I used them for years, they kinda sorta work but better for wider tires rather than 28mm road tires.
data.author: Fred Dixon
